Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Commercialization of Lead-free Nanosolder Paste for Micro/Nano-Electronics Assembly and Packaging
Award.AbstractNarration:
Soldering is widely used in electronics manufacturing. Traditionally, tin/lead (Sn/Pb) solders are most widely used. Recently, due to the toxicity and health concerns of lead, Sn/Pb solders are being phased out and Pb-free solders are more widely used. However, most Pb-free solders have a higher melting temperature than Sn/Pb solders and thus impose thermal stress and reliability issues for the printed circuit boards (PCBs) and electronic devices. Nanosolders have the potential to replace or improve the existing micron-sized Pb-free solder powders and to meet the increasing demand in the electronics sector. Furthermore, with the electronics industry's focus on further miniaturization and push to 'nanoelectronics', nanosolders are expected to play a key role in assembling nano-components into nanoelectronics and nanosystems. The successful adoption of nanosolder materials will initiate a new epoch in micro/nano-electronics manufacturing. The smaller sized solder bumps will also promote the revolution of industrial soldering and electronics assembling methods. The lead-free formulation will reduce the usage of toxic material and provide a sustainable approach for future electronics manufacturing.

The objective of this I-Corps proposal is to investigate the commercialization feasibility of lead-free nanosolder paste, which has great potential as a new soldering material for micro/nano-electronics assembly and packaging applications. Specific aims include the development of a technology transfer plan, determination of industrial target and market value of lead-free nanosolder materials, and completion of a detailed commercialization plan for the potential application of lead-free nanosolder materials and nano-soldering technique. Recently, the lead-free nanosolder formulated paste has been developed as the direct replacement of the typical microsolder paste. This innovation is able to satisfy the current solder paste printing technology which has been widely adopted by the electronics manufacturing industry. The mechanical property studies showed that the nanosolder composed solders resulted in enhanced strength
when compared to the currently commercial formulated solder paste. For the next generation nanoelectronics, multiple nanocomponents, such as nanowire, nanotube and graphene, can be effectively jointed by applying nanoscale solder materials to form a functional device.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Soldering is widely used in electronics assembly and packaging processes for electronics manufacturing. Traditionally, tin/lead (Sn/Pb) solders are most widely used. Recently, due to the toxicity and health concerns of lead, Sn/Pb solders are being phased out and Pb-free solders are more widely adopted. However, most Pb-free solders have a higher melting temperature than Sn/Pb solders and thus impose thermal stress and reliability issues for the printed circuit boards (PCBs) and electronic devices. Nanosolders have the potential to replace or improve the existing micron-sized Pb-free solder powders and to meet the increasing demand in the electronics sector. Furthermore, with the electronics industry's focus on further miniaturization to nanoelectronics and devices, nanosolders are expected to play a key role in assembling nano-components into nanoelectronics and nanosystems. This I-Corps project investigated the commercialization feasibility of lead-free nanosolder paste, which has great potential as a new soldering material for micro/nano-electronics assembly and packaging applications. The entrepreneurial lead (EL) of the project, a postdoctoral researcher, with the assistance of the Mentor and Principle Investigator (PI), conducted many interviews (total about 100 persons in different companies) in various industrial sectors, participated in two NSF organized I-Corps Workshops and weekly online trainings, explored potential industrial customers and market value of lead-free nanosolder materials, and completed a detailed commercialization plan for the potential application of lead-free nanosolder materials and nano-soldering technique. The project provided a unique training opportunity for the postdoctoral researcher to learn the knowledge and skills of entrepreneurial experiences and build up the industrial network, which helped her for her future professional career development. The project also provided the PI a valuable experience in exploring potential technology transfer ways for the nanosolder paste, either through licensing or a possible start-up company. The lead-free nanosolder paste, once adopted, helps reduce the usage of toxic material and provide a more sustainable approach for future electronics manufacturing. The nanosolder paste also has the potential to be applied for assembling and packaging processes in other industrial fields, such as MEMS/NEMS devices, optical devices, defense and aerospace, and medical devices.


Last Modified: 11/13/2016
Modified by: Zhiyong Gu

Nanosolders have the potential to replace or improve the existing micron-sized Pb-free solder powders and to meet the increasing demand in the electronics sector. Furthermore, with the electronics industry's focus on further miniaturization to nanoelectronics and devices, nanosolders are expected to play a key role in assembling nano-components into nanoelectronics and nanosystems. This I-Corps project investigated the commercialization feasibility of lead-free nanosolder paste, which has great potential as a new soldering material for micro/nano-electronics assembly and packaging applications. The entrepreneurial lead (EL) of the project, a postdoctoral researcher, with the assistance of the Mentor and Principle Investigator (PI), conducted many interviews (total about 100 persons in different companies) in various industrial sectors, participated in two NSF organized I-Corps Workshops and weekly online trainings, explored potential industrial customers and market value of lead-free nanosolder materials, and completed a detailed commercialization plan for the potential application of lead-free nanosolder materials and nano-soldering technique. The project provided a unique training opportunity for the postdoctoral researcher to learn the knowledge and skills of entrepreneurial experiences and build up the industrial network, which helped her for her future professional career development. The project also provided the PI a valuable experience in exploring potential technology transfer ways for the nanosolder paste, either through licensing or a possible start-up company. The lead-free nanosolder paste, once adopted, helps reduce the usage of toxic material and provide a more sustainable approach for future electronics manufacturing. The nanosolder paste also has the potential to be applied for assembling and packaging processes in other industrial fields, such as MEMS/NEMS devices, optical devices, defense and aerospace, and medical devices.
